awd_titl_txt: Qualitative Properties of Solutions to Nonlinear Elliptic Partial Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on central problems in classical fields of analysis such as the calculus of variations and free boundary problems.  The problems under investigation share some common features and have roots in different areas like material sciences, fluid mechanics, geometry, cost optimization etc.  They are relevant to both pure and applied mathematics. The proposed problems require progress on the known methods and techniques and addressing them would be beneficial for mathematicians and possibly for the larger scientific community as well.  The outcome will be disseminated to the interested audience to invigorate the advancement of the theory.  

A central part of the project deals with the stability of singular minimizing maps of smooth, convex energies that appear in nonlinear elasticity. The PI will investigate the singularity formation in the associated parabolic flow and the regularity of solutions to a class of elliptic systems with special structure.  Another part of the project is concerned with problems in nonlinear elliptic equations. The PI shall study the boundary behavior of some degenerate Monge-Ampere equations and optimal transportation problems, and to develop Pogorelov type estimates for some interesting model equation.  In free boundaries, the PI will study the two-phase free boundary problem for different operators together with various obstacle-type problems, and will also analyze the rigidity of boundary layer phase transitions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The project focused on various questions about regularity of solutions to elliptic PDEs which arise in the calculus of variations, geometry and free boundary problems. 

 The PI developed novel methods in several problems of interests. For example in the optimal transportation problem he obtained the sharp estimates for the transport map between densities supported on arbitrarily convex planar domains. This includes the challenging case when the densities are allowed to vanish near the boundary. In a related project he investigated the behavior of solutions to the Monge-Ampere equation in non-smooth domains with corners. He also introduced and studied a novel equation that exhibits a mixed group of invariances. 

 A large part of the project was devoted to free boundary problems. On this topic the PI developed a robust technique for establishing the regularity of the non-degenerate part of the free boundary in the one-phase Stefan problem. Sharp results regarding the geometry of free boundaries were obtained in other classical problems such as the nonlinear obstacle problem, the thin obstacle problem, and the multiple membranes problem.

 In another direction the PI revisited and simplified some proofs of the boundary Harnack principle. 

  The results achieved in this project have been disseminated to the scientific community through participation to conferences and seminars. They also opened up several future directions of research.

 


Last Modified: 02/10/2023
Modified by: Ovidiu Savin
